reviewText:
This game will either make you to quit in frustration or teach you patience until you become a rope master.

People who cannot easily get satisfaction with non challenging games, are going to appreciate it, like I did.

For free, it shines amongst many other (hard) platformers even with its short length. Though 'short' is such a relative term for this game!
voteText: 54 of 62 people (87%) found this review helpful 6 people found this review funny

reviewText:
I'll be honest, the description and reviews of this game are terrible. I'm going to try to describe it properly. Ignore absolutely EVERYTHING else you have read about the game, including the official description.

I don't know who Fork Parker is at all and you don't have to either. He's a crotchety looking bald guy in a suit who has to climb a mountain and will probably die a lot, but has loads of checkpoints along the way and infinite lives. Yep, it's an indie platformer.

But wait, wait, wait. There's a gimmick here and it's actually quite clever. Fork can shoot pitons. Wherever they land, a rope will immediately connect the two pitons, up to about three ropes. He slides along these ropes with his cane, so momentum along the ropes is important to consider even though you can jump jump jump to climb a downward facing rope.

So you are making your own platforms generally. And it's good fun too.

The game is about an hour and a half long, with speedrunning, no death, full collection achievements out there. It's quick, to the point, and good fun, so replayability is solid. The difficulty curve is slow and steady, but it definitely ends tougher than it begins. At the base of the mountain you can climb without even firing a piton and toward the top everything is spikes so you are leaping from rope to rope.

The controls aren't perfect. The rope sliding physics are a bit irritating, but for the most part it is a fun game. It is definitely worth your time.
voteText: 53 of 66 people (80%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
A mixture of rainbow island meets super meat boy, Fork Parkers Holiday Hike basically acts as a simulator game to Devolver Digitals CFO Fork Parker. The story here is that as CFO Fork has been tasked by the other board members to increase Digitals revenue for the 4th fiscal quarter; what entails after is a long trek throughout a perilous mountain attacked by various ice dwelling creatures such as Penguins, Yeti's, Cool dude snowmen (who look suspiciously like Cool spot) and sentient holiday sweaters!

Fork must carefully outmanoeuvre these threats as well as the various environmental hazards that litter the mountain, in his bid to reach the summit and obtain the most profit he possibly can. When playing as fork the game acts like Super meat boy; Fork can walk and jump however holding down the run button allows Fork to run faster and jump greater distances he also has a wall jump and slide ability that allows him to navigate tricky crevices and platforms, additionally for harder to reach places Fork can place hiking ropes (up to 3 at a time) around the environment.

By attaching ropes to two hard surfaces fork can create a pulley line that allows him to zip from one end to the other, this is where the real skill of the game comes into play, it becomes more and more necessary to place ropes around areas to avoid traps and progress up the summit, as the player progresses the need to use the ability of rope zipping becomes more crucial; the game luckily eases you into things at the start of the summit you're just required to put a couple of ropes down and move from A to B, later on however things become much more frantic with Fork required to place down various ropes between two pillars of spikes, the idea is that you're learning the skills comfortably at the start of the game which become essential and more frantic in the later halves. Additionally like Forks running skills the ropes hook placement can also be affected by velocity, holding the run button/key while firing a hook will increase it's range and speed and it will become paramount that players correctly understand and identify where their hooks need to go.

Overall Fork Parkers Holiday Hike is a fun, solid little adventure, it's difficult, just like the games it takes it's cues from but there's a deeply satisfying feeling to being stumped in one area and then overcoming the problem with some thorough thinking and creative use of the rope mechanic. Death serves a rather comedic detriment as in SMB this game is more about overcoming the challenges and your own foibles than relentlessly punishing you, checkpoints are plentiful and the game is designed fairly; when you fail you feel like it was your own fault as opposed to the game, still the difficulty can be a turn off for some.

As a free game you really can't go wrong with FPHH, it exudes charm and finally gives Devolvers charismatic Fork Parker a day in the limelight, really when all is said and done this game offers a nice little diversion from the larger Steam sales currently on offer, I wholeheartedly recommend everyone to pick this game up and give it a try!

reviewText:
This game was NOT FREE TO PLAY.  It cost me $20000 in medical expenses.


Edit:

But in all seriousness, this game is really fun.  For those of you who took the initial review seriously, no, it did not cost me $20000 in medical expenses to play this game.  The game is 100% free, and though it is short (it takes like 10-15minutes to speed through) it is really hard, and very enjoyable.  It's got killer sweaters, killer penguins, killer snowmen, killer snow..spike...things.  You get the point; lots of ways to die, but it's still alot of fun.

I personally suck at platformers, which is why I only dropped 15 or so minutes on this, but for those that like that kind of game, you're going to like this.  It's semi-mindless, and really has no point, but it seems to do well without one.  Looking forward to seeing more from this developer.

reviewText:
A much more developed and heart breaking tale of the difficulties of the gaming industry than Indie Game The Movie.
Gives you an insight of the life of a fellow man who wants to break all established rules and find developers who can get him enough monies to pay the thousands hospital debts and the party cocaine they consumed at the airport on their way to PlayStation event.
As you climb and loose again and again do to sh*tty keaboard controls, you realize the paradox that they are trying to make, make a reflection of the harsh challenge of his job, as he can bearly survive an ice pick with sharp ends, just as he has to deal with EA executives and weird twitter responses.

Overall, im quite enjoying this, and made me respect Devolver even more, despite your games made a friend of mine want to date birds and keeps making annoying comments over Serious Sam 4 and why it will burst gamers a new a--hole.

So yea, its quite charming in its own right. However, dont melt the ice of the game, or there will be water.And IGN hates water, its a fact.

reviewText:
Sort of fun game even though the controls and movement take a while of getting used to. In fact, I would say the movement should be smoother than it is now. Grabbing all the money took a lot of trial and error and even if replaying the game, it's pretty hard to grab all of it especially in one run if you want to get all achievements... I could only play the game in short bursts because the last few obstacles were rather frustrating to to do for the first time without proper strategy.

There are a few bugs that can cause death, for example getting stuck under a block of snow (not the pure snow block, but ground one). Probably intended, but jumping on snowballs can be frustrating; sometimes although it looks like you jump directly on top of them, you don't - and die instead.

9/10

Edit: After my second run I discovered that if you hold shift while placing your ropes, you can throw it extra far... finding this out made the game much easier.

On my first run the game took an hour, on the second run 26 minutes, on third run 15 minutes and on the fourth I cleared it in 10. Now I'm finding it rather easy to finish the game in under 10 min even without deaths (the only hard parts for me: the snowball part and the very last climbing part).

reviewText:
After Tofu: The Trials of Chi, Dungeon Hearts and Defense Technica, this is the next big thing from Devolver Digital. The worlds second famous game publisher after Activision. Sure, it's a no brainer in case you struggle to load this game or not. Because it's free. And I don't mean the kind of free that you get on bittorrent or some shady Youtube-link with survey attached on it. The game is free because Fork Parker is such a great entrepreneur that pulls away the cash-barrier between the player and the game and he still generates money through the process of distributing the game. This is a thing you only learn in the first world.

To the game itself:

I think so far it's the best game starring Fork Parker.

reviewText:
When it comes to platformers I love them frustratingly hard. Fork Parker's Holiday Profit Hike delivers on difficulty, and is free, so there's little reason for you to dislike it. Super Meat Boy often came to mind whilst playing

The gameplay is simple, you run, jump, and fire pitons to stick into the ice, creating ropes that you can slide on to better traverse obstacles. As with all platformers, the gameplay itself starts out straightforward and easy, and with your mastery of the aspects of the game and ascendance of the mountain, it will get more and more challenging

There are plenty of achievements if you're so inclined towards them as a means of proving your skill and e-peen size to the world, and they're your standard kind for platformers, beat the game without dying, speedrun the game, get all the collectibles etc

The goal of the game is to reach the top of the mountain with as much cash as possible, you lose $5000 per death and typically gain $10000 per bag with a couple of $20000 bags and 2 $100K eggs. You get a short ending based on whether you end up positive or negative by the time you reach the summit, but beyond that and the achievements tied to collection there's little incentive to grab up the bags besides the enticing sound effect they produce upon collection.

I believe when it comes to platformers you have to get the controls completely 100% perfectly refined, that is your duty as a developer. FPHPH's controls are tight, but they're not perfect. Probably the most unrefined aspect of the game is enemy bopping. You can spring off the top of enemies to gain some height and immobilize them temporarily, but the problem is, you must hit the very top of the enemy, and you cannot approach them from the side to achieve this goal, or you will die and be whisked back to a checkpoint.

This got very frustrating, especially when trying to bounce off of snowballs. In any other platforming game in history, I would have been fine and dandy, but there is such a small specific hitbox for bopping enemies in this game that it feels unintuitive and unrefined.

Another thing I found somewhat unsatisfying is sliding down ropes you've created. You maintain the momentum you established when you grappled onto the rope whilst you slide down it. There are many points in the game where you must grapple from rope to rope in quick succession whilst dancing around very cramped death obstacles, and I found that 90% of the time I was killed, it was because I failed to negate my momentum fast enough by jumping off of the rope before sliding. Holding the LT on a controller will make you lose all momentum and stay still on the ground whilst running, but has no effect whilst sliding on ropes. I feel like this would have been a very good addition and made deaths feel far more fair

Look the game's free, and will get you past a boring afternoon, so I recommend this game to platforming fans, expect enjoyment, but don't expect the second coming of Super Meat Christ

reviewText: This game is awesome. I don't understand why, but this game is just purelly awesome.
Profits? What profits? I lost SO MUCH MONEY in medical bills.

This game makes Super Meat Boy look super easy.  Fork Parkers Holiday Profit Hike is definitely a game for a true masochist.  This is not necessarily a good thing however. The game is fun, but it goes about difficulty by making the level design poor and the controls feel super clunky. The majority of your deaths might not even end up being your fault, I cant count how many times I died because my character decided he wanted to grab a ledge or rope even when your trying to avoid that very thing!  I imagine its not that big of a deal because the game is free though, after all generally speaking price = quality in most cases. In the end I feel that Fork Parker's Holiday profit Hike is a decent platformer and  I recommend this game for people who like platformers and probably frustration.


EDIT: It seems there may be a bug involving passing through ropes and jumping at this time. I dont know if this has been fixed or not by the time you are reading this, but I see a few people reporting similar issues at the time of writing this review. Who knows what may come of it? Maybe a patch or something if its not an isolated issue.

reviewText:
Just finished getting 100% with this one. I have to say, I was quite pleased with it. For a free offering it's very well designed, with some interesting (and fun) mechanincs.

Keyboard controls aren't great, but they do recommend playing it with a controller, so I won't complain about that. For what it's worth I used a PS2 controller, and it worked perfectly.

Bottom line is I would recommend this one. I should also note that it only saves at checkpoints, so if you're having trouble with some of the trickier achievements, you can return to the menu from the options and retry as many times as you like. It might not be as satisfying as doing it legit, but it worked for me, and will save you a lot of time and frustration.

reviewText:
PROS
1. Looked fun to play
Looked like a snow climbing game with an old generic-looking CEO archetype pasted on to be the protagonist.

2. Free
I believe this speaks for itself.

CONS
1. Horrible PS4 Controller support
Solvable if you use the keyboard to change the mode from Automatic to Manual but it ♥♥♥♥♥♥ me off for the first ten minutes.

2. Tricky
Sadly, it is not that fun. Despite the challenge, the reward does not justify the difficulty. You shoot a points join up, you jump all over the place on a rope, then you get nothing but the next part all over again.

reviewText:
Only free if you don't count the broken 360 controller.. because i ended up throwing mine at the wall.

The concept is fun, but the controls ruin it.. walking around and throwing the 'piton' things works great, but more often than not, the character just DOES NOT JUMP when i need him to (especially when running, he just drops off the edge as if i didn't even press the button, time and time again)
Jumping on enemies stops them for a few secs, but does not kill them.. which is humane, i guess, but mostly works against you (as an example, around 105m, you need to jump on a penguin to get to a bag of money, but the bag is surrounded by spikes, so you need to land not-on-the-penguin, or you're dead .. but there's almost no room to actually pull this off)

Also, when i downloaded the game yesterday, it apparentlty had steam trading cards, yet today it doesn't anymore?

reviewText:
Bad controls.
W and the Up Arrow do not have a jump option and they cannot be changed. The other controls are shoved in the corner of your keyboard and it can be complicated just to fire a long range hook with the amount of button pressing it takes to get anywhere.
Going straight up on a hook turns into a Mario Party game with mashing one button, since Fork is only good at climbing and leaping left and right.
It's a small sized game but the trailer shows the jist of the game. Fire left and right and don't try doing anything interesting.

A really cool platform game where you control Fork Parker trying to climb a mountaine collecting moneys to save his company while avoiding enemies, snowballs and spikes. You can throw pitons on surfaces to create a rope you can hang on like some sort of zip-line to reach some parts of the map, that's the game's main feature since you have to use them to get trough most of the game's sections.\nThe game is pretty hard but funny to play, the character's movement are fluid and making him run and jump around the mountain is simple and funny; it just makes the game a lot more entartaining and intresting.\nTechnically speaking the game has a cool art-style with a pixellated" graphic and "modern" dynamic lights and shadows that make for a great aesthetic
date: Fork's animations are amazing and funny! I really suggest playing it if you want a challenging Platform Game."

A surprisingly fun game for those who are bored and feel the need to rage a little. This is a great holiday game with awesome mechanics (not to mention the graphics are retroey-goodness). I would probably pay up to 5$ for this game, but since its free, I dont have too!

Pros:
+Funny
+Good layout of maps
+Old school graphics
+Good mechanics
+A little rage inducing

Prons(The meh stuff):
=Decent engine
=Ropes are a little annoying but are fairly easy to get used too
=Short game

Cons:
-The monsters are WAAYYY overpowered. At least add a life system considering everything
is pretty much is so its really hard to control movement
-Ropes can sometimes glitch
-Needs tutorial. At least an intro level.

Thats really all I have after my current experiance of the game. Maybe a 2015 version will come out?...

Anyways this is my opinion and I could be totally wrong, just feedback from my perspective.

Through many pixels, hours of hiking, and making much profit, I am finally ready to write a review for Fork Parker's Holiday Profit Hike.

Pros:
Let's start off by saying what we all already know. The game is a masterpiece. The immense detail and work put into every pixel of your hike is mind-blowing. I was amazed by the great visial representation of Fork Parker's face. Though the visuals may be extraordinary, the story was what really captivated me. Fork Parker must go though many segments of emotional and physical pain to achieve his important goal of profit. Fork is caught between his love for profit and the holiday spirit of giving, forcing Fork to decide if the hike is really all about the profit, or giving. The story is an incredibly detailed drama/action adventure with a side of romance (Fork and his profit) that left me thinking about it for days after I completed my first hike. Now, let's move on to the soundtrack. I remember being blown away when I first started up the game and hearing the amazing and exquisite original soundtrack.

Cons:
Honestly, the game has no flaws, other than sometimes I find myself wishing for more profit.

Verdict:
Overall, the game is a MASTERPIECE. It contains hours of story, captivating gameplay mechanics, and profit hiking.

This game is similar to Meat Boy, VVVVV, I Wanna Be The Guy etc. where you have to dodge hazards as you die and respawn. It has few elements which reminds me of DuckTales, such as being a grumpy old man who collects money bags and able to jump on top of enemies. What makes this game unique is that you're constantly ascending the mountain, so it all takes place in one level.

The game has a lot of checkpoints. If you stop and come back, it loads from the last checkpoint, so it isn't too difficult or unfair.

The game also allows the player to experiment how to get over some parts with different solutions (such as using the rope vs. jumping/wallkicks or gaining momentum from enemies). The real challenge comes from trying to get top on the mountain with positive balance without dying too much.

The only issue with the game was its huge resolution which can't be adjusted normally, so I wish it had proper display settings.
This game is fun, but it is HARD. Be prepared to be frustrated.

A short but also somewhat lengthy free platformer featuring the almighty CFO at Devolver Digital, Fork Parker, who is on a quest to parkour up a mountain for the purpose of re-earning his lost dosh.

As far as I know you can't switch to windowed mode or change the resolution.
Because of its precision-platforming nature and heavy use of directional buttons a controller was highly preferred here.

You only go through one map but with it being a pretty difficult platformer it may take longer than you'd like although there are a bunch of checkpoints here that also serve as auto-saves.
Throughout the game there's money lying around that serve as collectible items or high score. Lives are unlimited however every time you die you lose a small portion of Mr. Parker's hard-earned cash. The sum total you earn can even go down to the negatives which would lead to a sad, tearful ending so should you reach the top of the mountain with zero or negative money.

There's the basic platforming that works and controls very well, and then there's the fancy pitons that Mr. Parker can utilize. The pitons are thrown to make ropes as they land on a proper surface when at least two are out (four max can be out as the earliest one will disappear when another is thrown) and then be used for various purposes such as reaching higher spots by climbing the piton-made ropes or going over obstacles with them.

It's free, the gameplay's very decent, you play as a very agile Fork Parker, and it's Christmas-y.

Fork Parker is my hero. I pray to Fork everyday. Fork is love, Fork is life.

But in all honesty, Fork Parker's Holiday blah blah blah (I'll call it Fork P. from now on,) is pretty amazing. Not being the best at platforms, I found Fork P. to be a fairly hard challenge, and I'm yet to beat the game. The start may discourage some, as I did find some trouble changing the controls (I just got used to the current ones) and a lot of the challenges are very hard. But once I took a second to breath, and realize that Fork P. is meant as a game, it became a lot more enjoyable.

The pixelized game design has a very retro appeal, which is suited nicely with the music. The opening scene is very funny and shows light to some laughable sarcasm. The enemies are fun, and the way the map is laid out, some sections with enemies are very hard to complete. I have no issues there.

What shines out in the game are definitely the ropes. Without the ropes, the game is impossible to beat. The ropes makes me feel like I'm a middle aged Spiderman, soaring through the mountain as I die over and over again.

I rate it an 8.5/10. It's very fun, and although I didn't like it at first, give Fork P. a try. Trust me.
